Belgium | language = French | budget = $17.3 million{{cite web|url=http://www.cnc.fr/web/fr/etudes/-/ressources/1567924|title=Film production in 2011|date=27 February 2012|publisher=[[National Center of Cinematography and the moving image|CNC]]|language=French|accessdate=28 May 2013}} | gross = $10.5 million{{cite web|url=http://www.jpbox-office.com/fichfilm.php?id=13015|title=Populaire (2012)|publisher=JP' Box-Office|accessdate=17 February 2014}} }} '''''Populaire''''' is a 2012 French romantic comedy-drama film directed by Régis Roinsard. It was co-written by Roinsard, Daniel Presley and Romain Compingt. ''Populaire'' was released in France on 28 November 2012. The film's title is taken from the name of the typewriter (Japy Populaire) used in the film. ''Populaire'' tells the story of Rose Pamphyle ([[Déborah François]]), who is trained by Louis Échard ([[Romain Duris]]) to become the fastest typist in the world through winning the 1959 international [[speed typing contest]] in New York City. ==Plot== Set in 1958–1959, ''Populaire'' focuses on Rose Pamphyle ([[Déborah François]]), who lives with her widowed father and is destined to marry a son of the local mechanic. Rose travels out of town and applies for a secretarial job with an insurance agency run by Louis Échard ([[Romain Duris]]). Louis learns that Rose can type with extraordinary speed -- using only two fingers -- and he tells her to compete in a speed-typing competition if she wants the job. While Rose makes the finals, she ultimately loses her first typing competition. Louis begins training Rose to become the fastest typist in the world. He makes a bet with his best friend, Bob Taylor -- who is married to his old sweetheart, Marie -- that Rose can win the regional competition. Louis begins to train Rose at his home, but he sets strict rules to prevent others from knowing that Rose is staying in his boyhood bedroom. He begins to teach her to [[touch typing|type with all ten fingers]] and Louis insists she take [[piano lesson]]s (taught by Marie) to strengthen her fingers. As she struggles to learn to type with ten fingers, Louis encourages her, colour-coding the keys on her typewriter and [[ergonomy|teaching her better posture]]. As the seasons change, she excels and Louis and Rose become close friends. Rose wins her second typing competition, becoming the fastest in her home region of [[Lower Normandy]]. It becomes obvious to Louis' friends that Louis and Rose are romantically interested in each other, but Louis insists that a coach mustn't distract his student. They travel together to Paris and the night before the French national competition, Louis and Rose announce their love to one another and have sex. Competing against the current national champion, Rose makes it to the finals, but struggles under the pressure. Before her final match, Louis tells Rose that he had been lying and that he has secretly been recording that her typing speed is regularly faster than her opponent's best record. Angered by his lie, Rose is enraged into winning. Rose is ecstatic at winning and flashes Louis a big smile from on stage. After initially being elated, Louis begins to feel inadequate for somewhat ambiguous reasons. He abandons her and their training sessions. Rose stays in Paris and becomes a French celebrity, endorsed by a major typing firm and begins using their newest typewriter. She never forgets Louis and calls him regularly, although Louis never answers the phone. Louis tries to move on, but is generally depressed and feels inadequate. Rose begins to move on and is soon in New York at the world typing competition. While Rose starts the world competition in New York, Louis struggles with his own feelings. He reaches out to Marie and asks why she chose Bob over him. She says she didn't: Louis chose to be second place. Louis explains that he could never give Rose the smile and happiness the she had when she won in Paris -- the same smile that he saw on Marie on her wedding day to Bob. Marie says, "I was smiling because I felt loved." Louis realises he needs to overcome his own feelings of inadequacy and flies to New York to support Rose in the international typing competition. He arrives just before the second round of the finals ends. As the judges announce the results, Rose is behind and struggling. She runs back stage to fetch her old typewriter, and Louis confronts her and professes his love. They kiss. Rose goes on stage for the last round - seemingly energised by love. She races ahead in the final match. About half way in, her typewriter jams. She is too fast for the typewriter. She quickly recovers and races ahead again, winning the competition to be the World's Fastest Typist. Louis walks on stage and kisses her, ending the film on the two holding hands and the audience cheering. ==Cast== {{Div col |colwidth=30em}} * [[Déborah François]] as Rose Pamphyle * [[Romain Duris]] as Louis Échard * [[Bérénice Bejo]] as Marie Taylor * [[Shaun Benson]] as Bob Taylor * [[Mélanie Bernier]] as Annie Leprince-Ringuet * [[Féodor Atkine]] as André Japy * [[Nicolas Bedos]] as Gilbert Japy * [[Eddy Mitchell]] as Georges Échard * [[Miou-Miou]] as Madeleine Échard * Sara Haskell as Susan Hunter * [[Frédéric Pierrot]] as Jean Pamphyle * Jeanne Cohendy as Françoise * [[Dominique Reymond]] as Madamme Shorofsky * [[Caroline Tillette]] as La Vamp * Serpentine Teyssier as Mrs. Teyssier * Marius Colucci as Lucien Échard * Emeline Bayart as Jacqueline Échard * Yannik Landrein as Léonard Échard * Nastassja Girard as Evelyne Échard * Pauline Morro as Simone Taylor * Hugo de Sousa as Joe Taylor * [[Fanny Sidney]] as The fan * Joan Mompart as Cha-cha-chá singer {{div col end}} ==Production== ===Casting=== [[File:Déborah François at the 2009 Deauville American Film Festival-01.jpg|thumb|165px|Belgian actress [[Déborah François]] plays Rose Pamphyle.]] Roinsard was planning to cast an unknown actress in the lead role of Rose Pamphyle, but chose Belgian actress [[Déborah François]] after she impressed him in her audition.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/starsandstories/10076969/Deborah-Francois-interview-for-Populaire-Acting-felt-like-a-fantasy.html|title=Déborah François interview for Populaire: 'Acting felt like a fantasy'|last=Dehn|first=Georgia|date=27 May 2013|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|publisher=[[Telegraph Media Group]]|accessdate=1 June 2013}} After asking her father to find a typewriter for her, François practised for a week before the audition. She told Georgia Dehn from ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', "I was so fast at the audition that everyone watching asked whether I had done it much before. Of course I didn't admit to practising. I told them, 'I'm just really motivated, I really want the part, I'm ready for competition.'" François believed that she connected with Rose as soon as she finished reading the script. She loved Rose's clumsiness and thought she was a bit like herself. François underwent six months of professional typing coaching before filming commenced. She had to practice for up to three hours every day. The actress explained that as they wanted it to be real, nothing is sped up in the film and her hands are featured in every scene. [[Romain Duris]] was cast as Louis Échard. Duris was initially concerned about whether the costumes and style would take over causing the film to be stuck in the past. He said he needed the film to feel live and real.{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/arts-ents/film/chic-cheerful.20111991|title=Chic cheerful|last=Mowe|first=Richard|date=9 February 2013|work=[[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]]|publisher=[[Newsquest]]|accessdate=1 June 2013}} The actor watched several films starring [[Cary Grant]] and [[James Stewart]] as well as French classics directed by [[Marcel Carné]] and [[Claude Chabrol]] to see the differences between the provinces and Paris and the ways in which people behaved and spoke in the 1950s. ===Costume design=== Costume designer Charlotte David created and designed many of the clothes for the film. David previously created costumes for ''[[OSS 117: Cairo, Nest of Spies]]'', which was also set in France in the fifties.{{cite web|url=http://www.wwd.com/eye/design/mad-hommes-behind-the-scenes-of-populaire-6502948|title=Mad Hommes: Behind the Scenes of 'Populaire'|last=Guilbault|first=Laure|date=27 November 2012|work=[[Women's Wear Daily]]|publisher=[[Fairchild Fashion Media]]|accessdate=28 May 2013}} Laure Guilbault from ''[[Women's Wear Daily]]'' reported that the look of ''Populaire'' was inspired by ''[[Funny Face]]'', ''[[The Seven Year Itch]]'' and [[Alfred Hitchcock]] films. François revealed that she gave her own input for the costumes, saying "I loved being involved in the creation of costumes. I could say that these suspenders should be thinner, or this skirt should be worn with an extra petticoat, or have a bow added." David thought the right lingerie was crucial to the look and pointy bras, girdles and bodices were used to underpin the silhouettes. Some of the lingerie was made by Parisian corsetry house [[Cadolle]]. As Rose is "a young provincial woman", she often wears pretty dresses, while Bejo's character Marie, who is married to an American man, has a casual early Sixties look. David explained that she wanted Marie to be a modern woman and she found printed fabrics for her costumes at De Gilles, a fabric shop in Paris, which she used to make short pants. She then completed the look with silk knit jerseys, ballet shoes, headbands and tight cardigans. Lelia Delval, the hairstylist for ''Populaire'', gave Bejo a red wig to wear, which the actress liked so much, she dyed her real hair red for her next film. The men wore tailor-made suits and [[tie clip]]s. Duris' character Louis sports a vintage [[Jaeger-LeCoultre]] watch. ===Music=== The musical score of the film was written by French artists Rob and Emmanuel d'Orlando. The soundtrack also uses pre-existing music tracks. It was released on 28 November 2012.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Populaire-Bande-originale-du-film/dp/B00A96TVCS|title=Populaire (Bande originale du film)|publisher=[[Amazon.com|Amazon.co.uk]]|accessdate=28 May 2013}} Roinsard decided to use music from three years before and after the year in which the film takes place.{{cite web|url=http://www.wearemoviegeeks.com/2013/05/populaire-trailer-debuts-conversations-with-director-regis-roinsard-actress-berenice-bejo/|title=Conversations With Director Régis Roinsard & Actress Bérénice Béjo|last=McCue|first=Michelle|date=7 May 2013|publisher=We Are Movie Geeks|accessdate=28 May 2013}} When choosing the pre-existing music, Roinsard combined his love of American lounge music, light jazz and '50s composers with French songs by lesser-known artists such as Jack Ary, [[Jacqueline Boyer]] and [[Les Chaussettes Noires]], whose singer [[Eddy Mitchell]] appears in the film.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movie/populaire/review/388560|title=Populaire: Rome Review|last=Mintzer|first=Jordan|date=11 November 2012|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=28 May 2013}} Roinsard thought Rob and Emmanuel d'Orlando's score added "great emotional impact to the film." The director was inspired by both '50s and '60s recording methods for the score, which was recorded in France. Roinsard added "The end result is close to a musical and I'm delighted since [[Stanley Donen]] and [[Bob Fosse]] are favorites of mine." ==Release== ''Populaire'' had its world premiere at the Sarlat Film Festival. It was then released in France on 28 November 2012.{{cite web|url=http://festivaldufilmdesarlat.com/Les-films|title=World Tour|publisher=Sarlat Film Festival|language=French|accessdate=1 June 2013}} ''Populaire'' played at the [[Glasgow Film Festival]] in February, before it was released in the UK on 31 May 2013. The film was released on 6 September 2013 in the United States.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movie/populaire|title=Populaire (2013)|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=1 June 2013}} ==Reception== ===Critical response=== ''Populaire'' earned €406,295 upon its opening weekend in France. The film opened to 450 theatres and landed at number three in the French box office top ten.{{cite web|url=http://www.allocine.fr/boxoffice/boxofficedetail_gen_pays=5001.html?date=2012-11-28|title=Box Office France> Week of November 28, 2012|publisher=[[AlloCiné]]|language=French|accessdate=29 May 2013}} As of 28 May 2013, ''Populaire'' has grossed $5,315,819 worldwide.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=populaire.htm|title=Populaire|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=28 May 2013}} The review aggregator website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reported a 74% approval rating with an average rating of 6.7/10 based on 61 reviews. The website's consensus reads, "The cheerfully frothy ''Populaire'' may lack substance, but its visual appeal – and director Roinsard's confident evocation of 1950s filmmaking tropes – help carry the day."{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/populaire/|title=Populaire|publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=9 August 2015}} [[Metacritic]], which assigns a score of 1–100 to individual film reviews, gave ''Populaire'' an average rating of 57 based on 25 reviews, indicating "mixed or average reviews".{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/populaire|title=Populaire|publisher=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=9 August 2015}} Jérôme Vermelin from ''Metro France'' commented "Full of charm, this first film by young director Régis Roinsard is carried by an irresistible duo of Romain Duris and Deborah François."{{cite news|url=http://www.metronews.fr/culture/video-la-bande-annonce-de-populaire-avec-romain-duris/mlky!wtlGb64lcJ3sM/|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130701234317/http://www.metronews.fr/culture/video-la-bande-annonce-de-populaire-avec-romain-duris/mlky!wtlGb64lcJ3sM/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=1 July 2013|title=La bande-annonce de Populaire, avec Romain Duris|last=Vermelin|first=Jérôme|date=25 November 2012|work=Metro France|publisher=[[Metro International]]|language=French|accessdate=29 May 2013}} Liz Beardsworth from ''[[Empire (film magazine)|Empire]]'' gave ''Populaire'' three stars and wrote "Roinsard keeps control of a film that vacillates between frothy fun and more serious social comment and cleverly uses subplots and supporting characters (including ''The Artist's'' Bérénice Bejo) to touch on weightier themes. Quaint, but charming."{{cite web|url=http://www.empireonline.com/reviews/reviewcomplete.asp?FID=138143|title=Populaire|last=Beardsworth|first=Liz|work=[[Empire (film magazine)|Empire]]|publisher=[[Bauer Media Group]]|accessdate=28 May 2013}} [[IndieWire]]'s Kaleem Aftab awarded the film a B− and stated "With a great cast and sufficient laughs, ''Populaire'' could find international audiences, but it's no ''Amelie''. The orthodox script will not broaden appeal outside the dedicated romcom market and the language barrier may also be a problem for some."{{cite web|url=http://www.indiewire.com/article/rome-film-festival-review-why-the-funny-and-familiar-populaire-panders-to-u-s-audiences|title=Why the Funny and Familiar 'Populaire' Panders to U.S. Audiences|last=Aftab|first=Kaleem|date=11 November 2012|work=[[IndieWire]]|publisher=[[SnagFilms]]|accessdate=28 May 2013}} Boyd van Hoeij, writing for ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', said the film is "a colorful and impeccably styled romantic comedy that manages to turn the speed-typing competitions of the 1950s into entertaining cinematic fodder."{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2012/film/reviews/populaire-1117948804/|title=Review: "Populaire"|last=Hoeij|first=Boyd van|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[PMC (company)|Penske Media Corporation]]|accessdate=28 May 2013}} He went on to praise the performances of Duris and François, but thought the story did not quite take any unexpected turns or reveal any deeper emotions. ===Accolades=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" |- ! {{for|the Science and Science fiction concepts|Transliteracy|Postliterate society}} '''Post literacy''' or '''post literacy education''' is a concept used in [[continuing education]] and [[adult education]] programs aimed at recently [[illiterate]] or "neo-literate" adults and communities, largely in the [[developing world]]. Unlike continuing education or [[further education]], which covers secondary or vocational topics for adult learners, Post literacy programs provide skills which might otherwise be provided in [[primary education]] settings.<ref>Rogers, Alan. [http://www.eric.ed.gov/ERICWebPortal/contentdelivery/servlet/ERICServlet?accno=ED472436 Re-Thinking Adult Literacy and Post-Literacy: From an International Perspective]. The Roby Kidd Memorial Lecture. Uppingham Press (2002)</ref> Post literacy education aims to solidify literacy education, provide resources and media aimed at the newly literate, and also may create systems of non-formal education to serve these communities. Projects include providing formal continuing education, providing written materials (the [[literate environment]]) relevant to economic development to newly literate members of developing societies, and leveraging radio and other non-written media to increase access to educational material in informal settings.<ref>World Bank. [https://web.archive.org/web/20091023202124/http://web.worldbank.org/external/projects/main?pagePK=64283627&piPK=73230&theSitePK=40941&menuPK=228424&Projectid=P050752 Post-Literacy and Continuing Education for Human Development Project Bangladesh (2001)]. Accessed 2009-03-27 </ref>

A '''social employee''' is a worker operating within a [[social business model]]. Following an organization's social computing guidelines, social employees use [[social media]] tools both for internal [[workflow]] and [[collaboration]] purposes and for external engagement with customers, prospects and stakeholders through a combination of [[social media marketing]], [[content marketing]], [[social marketing]], and [[social selling]].<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|title = IBM Social Computing Guidelines|url = http://www.ibm.com/blogs/zz/en/guidelines.html|website = IBM|date = 2011-08-03|access-date = 2016-01-16|language = en-US}}</ref> Social employee programs are considered to be as much about culture and engagement as they are about business processes and best practices. In addition to increased leads and sales, social employee best practices are said to improve business outcomes important to social media marketing, such as increased connections and web traffic, improved brand identification and "chatter", and better customer advocacy.
== Overview == The term "social employee" was first introduced to describe those exhibiting the emerging characteristics of workers operating under a social business model. The concept gained broader recognition in late 2013 with the release of ''[http://bluefocusmarketing.com/book-the-social-employee/ The Social Employee]'', co-authored by marketing consultants Cheryl Burgess and Mark Burgess.<ref name=":0" /> In the book, the term was used to describe the end result of efforts of organizations such as [[IBM]], [[Adobe Systems|Adobe]], and [[Cisco Systems|Cisco]] to restructure their organizations, using a social business model and [[social computing]] principles to address the changing needs of both the workplace and their workers.<ref name=":7" />
The term is often used interchangeably with similar designations like "employee advocate" or "social employee advocate".<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://simplymeasured.com/blog/twitter-advocacy-how-one-employee-generated-massive-reach-for-thinkbonfire/#sm.0001sb7c3bmejd0nsti1jh62flf4c | title = Twitter Advocacy: How One Employee Generated Massive Reach for @ThinkBonfire {{!}} Simply Measured | website = Simply Measured | access-date = 2016-02-27 }}</ref> For prominent or upper-level social advocates, the terms "social leader" and "social executive" are often respectively used.<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/meghanbiro/2013/11/17/7-characteristics-of-a-social-leader/#3a3dceb963b1 | title = 7 Characteristics Of A Social Leader | website = Forbes | access-date = 2016-02-27 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.communityroundtable.com/grow/what-is-a-social-executive/ | title = What Is a Social Executive? - The Community Roundtable | website = The Community Roundtable | language = en-US | access-date = 2016-02-27 }}</ref>
Crucial to the perceived value of the social employee is the concept of the [[digital footprint]]. While organizations are able to generate large bases of followers through social media, research shows that [[brand marketing]] and [[brand engagement|engagement]] efforts through these networks are not as effective as those of individual employees.<ref name=":12">{{Cite web | url = https://business.linkedin.com/elevate | title = Employee Activation {{!}} LinkedIn Elevate | website = business.linkedin.com | language = en-us | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.socialmediatoday.com/content/employee-advocate-mobilize-your-team-share-your-brand-content | title = From Employee to Advocate: Mobilize Your Team to Share Your Brand Content | last = PaulDunay | website = Social Media Today | access-date = 2016-02-27 }}</ref> In fact, some research indicates that employee experts are more trusted than any other member of an organization.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.edelman.com/news/2016-edelman-trust-barometer-release/ | title = 2016 Edelman Trust Barometer | website = Edelman | language = en-US | access-date = 2016-02-27 }}</ref> Because of this, social employee programs are designed to train, empower, and support employee engagement efforts in the hopes of authentically engaging larger communities, increasing the frequency of shares, reviews, and other forms of "earned media" and expanding the brand's presence on the web.<ref name=":13" /><ref name=":14">{{Cite web | url = http://www.emarketer.com/Article/Social-Advocacy-Programs-Drive-Visibility-Businesses/1013377 | title = Social Advocacy Programs Drive Visibility for Businesses - eMarketer | website = www.emarketer.com | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref><ref name=":15">{{Cite web | url = http://www.socialchorus.com/advocate-powered-product-launches-lessons-learned-msn/ | title = Advocate Powered Product Launches: Best Practices from Microsoft {{!}} SocialChorus | website = SocialChorus | language = en-US | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref>
== The personal or employee brand == A foundational concept of the social employee is the idea of the personal or employee brand. This concept first gained popular attention in a 1997 [[Fast Company (magazine)|FastCompany]] article by business leader [[Tom Peters]] titled "The Brand Called You".<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.fastcompany.com/28905/brand-called-you|title = The Brand Called You|date = August 31, 1997|access-date = January 15, 2016|website = FastCompany|publisher = |last = Peters|first = Tom}}</ref> In the article, Peters argued that the premium placed on branding impacted workers' lives to such an extent that creating and cultivating a distinct personal brand had become a professional necessity. According to Peters, doing so built trust, loyalty, visibility, influence, and employability.
With increased adoption of social media tools by both businesses and consumers in the early 21st century, many business leaders became increasingly concerned with social engagement, both internally among employees and externally with customers and other stakeholders.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jure-klepic/to-engage-or-not-engage-e_b_3998928.html|title = To Engage or Not Engage Employees in Social Media—That Is the Question|date = October 1, 2013|access-date = January 15, 2016|website = Huffington Post|publisher = |last = Klepic|first = Jure}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.clomedia.com/blogs/3-social-workforce/post/redefining-the-social-employee|title = Redefining the Social Employee|date = June 18, 2012|access-date = January 15, 2016|website = Chief Learning Officer|publisher = MediaTec Publishing, Inc.|last = Pontefract|first = Dan}}</ref> While many in the business community acknowledged the potential social tools had for improved collaboration, productivity, and brand messaging, the concern that employees would misrepresent their brand, disclose proprietary information, or otherwise damage their company's reputation or ability to conduct business persisted.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url = https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2015/02/15/should-you-let-just-any-employee-tweet-about-your-company/eWMcp9r2LsBlS1WjBGKLiI/story.html|title = Should You Let Just Any Employee Tweet About Your Company?|date = February 15, 2015|access-date = January 15, 2016|website = The Boston Globe|publisher = |last = MIT Sloan Management Review}}</ref>
As a result, many began to advocate for employee branding as a solution to this problem. This helped give new meaning to the concept of [[brand ambassador]]ship, positioning everyday employees in public, and potentially high-profile, engagement roles.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url = https://www.icims.com/hire-expectations-institute/article-the-advantages-of-a-social-employee-engagement-strategy|title = The Advantages of a Social Employee Engagement Strategy|date = December 2, 2015|access-date = January 15, 2016|website = iCIMS|publisher = |last = Yee|first = Angela}}</ref> Proponents of this approach argued that successful employee engagement depended on training, strong [[organizational culture]], and individual empowerment.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url = http://www.business2community.com/branding/the-rise-of-the-employee-brand-0140637#Sr7BeGj6P7wVF3U0.97|title = The Rise of the Employee Brand|date = March 1, 2012|access-date = January 15, 2016|website = Business 2 Community|publisher = |last = Burgess|first = Cheryl}}</ref> This approach was seen as an example of a [[Win-win game|win-win]]: The corporate brand benefits from increased transparency and authenticity, while the personal brand benefits through increased visibility and employability.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FZUIp0ybaec|title = The Rise of the Social Employee|date = June 12, 2014|access-date = January 15, 2016|website = YouTube|publisher = TEDx Talks|last = Burgess|first = Mark}}</ref>
== Characteristics ==
=== Engaged === Because social employee advocacy is dependent on the perceived authenticity of the employee, [[Employee engagement|engagement]] is highly valued in social organizations. Further, data show the measurable impact of employee engagement on organizational productivity and profitability: * Happy employees were found to be 12 percent more productive.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.fastcompany.com/3048751/the-future-of-work/happy-employees-are-12-more-productive-at-work|title = Why Happy Employees Are 12% More Productive|date = July 22, 2015|access-date = January 15, 2016|website = FastCompany|publisher = |last = Revesencio|first = Jonha}}</ref> * In one study, engaged employees were found to be 38 percent more likely to produce at above-average rates.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.talentculture.com/6-eye-opening-employee-engagement-statistics/|title = 6 Eye-Opening Employee Engagement Statistics|date = July 2, 2014|access-date = January 15, 2016|website = TalentCulture|publisher = |last = Photiades|first = Melissa Dawn}}</ref> In another, organizations with engaged employees had a 19 percent higher than average shareholder return, while organizations with disengaged employees experienced shareholder return that was 44 percent below average.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.domo.com/blog/2013/05/employee-engagement-delivers-positive-returns/|title = Employee Engagement Delivers Positive Returns|date = May 2, 2013|access-date = January 18, 2016|website = Domo|publisher = |last = Kehoe|first = Julie}}</ref> * Engaged companies were found to outperform disengaged companies by up to 202 percent.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.dalecarnegie.com/employee-engagement/engaged-employees-infographic/|title = Engaged Employees Infographic|date = |access-date = January 15, 2016|website = |publisher = |last = Dale Carnegie Training}}</ref> * Companies with strong focus on culture were found to have an average 13.9 percent turnover rate, while those with a low focus experience were found to have a 48.4 percent turnover rate.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.entrepreneur.com/article/238640|title = It Really Pays to Have a Rich Company Culture [Infographic]|date = October 21, 2014|access-date = January 15, 2016|website = Entrepreneur|publisher = |last = Siu|first = Eric}}</ref>
=== Flexible job environment and work/life balance === The number of professionals working [[Mobile workspace|mobile or remote]] has risen considerably since 2010. While estimates vary, one study found that number of organizations with mobile or remote employees is expected to rise from 24 percent in 2012 to 89 percent by 2020.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url = https://www.citrix.com/content/dam/citrix/en_us/documents/products-solutions/workplace-of-the-future-a-global-market-research-report.pdf|title = Workplace of the Future: A Global Market Research Report|date = 2012|access-date = January 18, 2016|website = |publisher = |last = Citrix}}</ref> Other research has estimated that by 2020, 105.4 million professionals will work remotely in America, about 72.3 percent of the total workforce.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url = https://www.idc.com/getdoc.jsp?containerId=prUS25705415|title = IDC Forecasts U.S. Mobile Worker Population to Surpass 105 Million by 2020|date = June 23, 2015|access-date = January 18, 2016|website = IDC|publisher = |last = International Data Corporation (IDC)}}</ref>
This change has been linked to a rise in social technologies, including [[biometrics]], [[Wearable computer|wearables]], [[Near field communication|near-field communications]], and [[augmented reality]].<ref name=":5" /> Social employees have also put a greater emphasis on [[Work–life balance|work-life balance]], with many believing that advances in technology can directly support efforts in this area.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/03/05/career-success-means-work-life-balance_n_2812707.html|title = Career Success Means Work-Life Balance, Study Finds|date = March 5, 2013|access-date = January 18, 2016|website = Huffington Post|publisher = |last = Brooks|first = Chad}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/jacquelynsmith/2013/04/18/8-ways-to-achieve-better-work-life-balance/#2715e4857a0b5793c01d3a25|title = 8 Ways To Achieve Better Work-Life Balance|date = April 18, 2013|access-date = January 18, 2016|website = Forbes|publisher = |last = Smith|first = Jacquelyn}}</ref> Purported benefits of this shift include a more flexible workforce, reduced business costs, and greater organizational leverage in attracting and retaining top talent.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":5" />
=== Buys into the brand's story === In 2009, thought leader [[Simon Sinek]] presented a speech called "How Great Leaders Inspire Action" at a [[TEDx|TEDxPugetSound]] event. Sinek's central argument in this speech was, "People don't buy what you do. They buy why you do it."<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.ted.com/talks/simon_sinek_how_great_leaders_inspire_action?language=en|title = How Great Leaders Inspire Action|date = September 2009|access-date = January 18, 2016|website = TED|publisher = |last = Sinek|first = Simon}}</ref> This concept—that the story behind a business or product offering is a more compelling sales tool than the product itself—is frequently cited in [[social media marketing]] as a way to build authentic connections with stakeholders.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.entrepreneur.com/article/232069|title = There's an Art to Telling Your Brand's Story: 4 Ways to Get It Right|date = April 3, 2014|access-date = January 18, 2016|website = Entrepreneur|publisher = |last = Handley|first = Ann}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/work-in-progress/2013/09/24/how-to-write-brand-stories-that-build-emotional-connections/#1d43e79062e22b4020f862e2|title = How to Write Brand Stories that Build Emotional Connections|date = September 24, 2013|access-date = January 18, 2016|website = Forbes|publisher = |last = Gunelius|first = Susan}}</ref> However, others have argued that for employees to share a brand's story authentically, they must be engaged in that story themselves, and as a result, many companies have made storytelling part of their culture programs.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/sarahmckinney/2014/02/24/this-company-is-turning-the-power-of-storytelling-within-for-employees/#2715e4857a0b4db11bb1790b|title = This Company Is Turning The Power Of Storytelling Within (For Employees)|date = February 24, 2014|access-date = January 18, 2016|website = Forbes|publisher = |last = McKinney|first = Sarah}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.convinceandconvert.com/digital-marketing/storytelling/|title = How Internal Storytelling Impacts Company Culture|date = |access-date = January 18, 2016|website = Convince&Convert|publisher = |last = Klotz-Guest|first = Kathy}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.globoforce.com/gfblog/2014/transforming-company-culture-through-storytelling/|title = Transforming Company Culture Through Storytelling|date = March 6, 2014|access-date = January 18, 2016|website = Globoforce|publisher = |last = Jacobsen|first = Darcy}}</ref> The process of securing employee buy-in and ownership for a brand's story is commonly referred to as "branding from the inside out".<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.cmo.com/articles/2013/4/21/branding_from_the_in.html|title = Branding From the Inside Out|date = April 23, 2013|access-date = January 18, 2016|website = CMO.com|publisher = Adobe|last = Burgess|first = Cheryl}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://marketing.about.com/od/marketingyourbrand/a/internalbrand.htm|title = Branding From the Inside Out|date = November 25, 2014|access-date = January 18, 2016|website = About.com|publisher = |last = Lake|first = Laura}}</ref>
=== Collaborative === An implicit tenet in social business is that social technologies aren't a barrier to productivity, but rather a path to increased connectivity.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://marketinginsidergroup.com/social-media/social-employees-the-future-of-marketing/|title = Are Social Employees the Future of Marketing?|date = April 2, 2013|access-date = January 20, 2016|website = Marketing Insider Group|publisher = |last = Brenner|first = Michael}}</ref> The shift in [[enterprise software]] systems like [[IBM Connections]] to incorporate social communication models, such as [[Mention (blogging)|mentions]], [[wiki]]s, and [[News aggregator|newsfeeds]], reflects the changing communication dynamics within business. With an increase in diversity and sophistication in [[collaborative software]] platforms, social organizations have sought to find new creative ways to utilize these tools and secure employee buy-in around them.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://hbr.org/2015/04/why-no-one-uses-the-corporate-social-network|title = Why No One Uses the Corporate Social Network|date = April 7, 2015|access-date = January 20, 2016|website = Harvard Business Review|publisher = |last = Li|first = Charlene}}</ref>
[[Crowdsourcing]] has also become popular in social businesses. Examples include AT&T's program The Innovation Pipeline (TIP), begun in 2009, which has generated over 28,000 ideas that have led to over 75 projects with funding exceeding $44 million.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://dupress.com/articles/social-business-study-mit-smr/|title = Moving Beyond Marketing: Generating Social Business Value Across the Enterprise|last = Kane|date = July 15, 2014|journal = MIT Sloan Management Review|doi = |pmid = |access-date = January 21, 2015|display-authors=etal}}</ref> IBM has also put considerable resources into such processes, producing its social computing guidelines through employee crowdsourcing, as well as its Connections platform through the Technology Adoption Program (TAP), a more formalized crowdsourcing initiative.<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":7">{{Cite book|title = The Social Employee|last = Burgess|first = Cheryl|publisher = McGraw Hill Education|year = 2013|isbn = 978-0-07-181641-0|location = New York|pages = |last2 = Burgess|first2 = Mark}}</ref>
Another popular form of internal collaboration is the hack day, or [[hackathon]]. Organizations such as [[Netflix]], [[Facebook]], and [[IBM]] use hack days to pull employees out of their day-to-day work environments and encourage them to collaborate in nontraditional ways in an attempt to drive [[disruptive innovation]].<ref name=":7" /><ref>{{Cite web|title = The Netflix Tech Blog: Netflix Hack Day - Autumn 2015|url = http://techblog.netflix.com/2015/11/netflix-hack-day-autumn-2015.html|website = techblog.netflix.com|access-date = 2016-01-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Stay focused and keep hacking|url = https://www.facebook.com/notes/facebook-engineering/stay-focused-and-keep-hacking/10150842676418920|website = www.facebook.com|access-date = 2016-01-22}}</ref>
Social employees are often encouraged to seek external collaboration opportunities with customers and prospects.<ref>{{Cite web|title = How Collaboration Tools Can Turn Your Business Into A Social Enterprise|url = http://www.cio.com/article/2937401/social-collaboration/how-collaboration-tools-can-turn-your-business-into-a-social-enterprise.html|website = CIO|access-date = 2016-01-22|first = Paul|last = Trotter}}</ref> For example, Procter & Gamble introduced the Live Well Collaborative to connect with external stakeholders and develop products and services for the 50+ demographic.<ref>{{Cite web|title = How Procter & Gamble Uses External Ideas For Internal Innovation|url = http://sloanreview.mit.edu/article/how-procter-gamble-uses-external-ideas-for-internal-innovation/|website = MIT Sloan Management Review|access-date = 2016-01-22}}</ref> Beginning in 2010, [[Dell]] initiated Customer Advisory Panel (CAP) Days conferences to put customers and employees in direct contact with each other. The initial program proved very popular for the organization, with over 128 million CAP-related impressions generated on Twitter.<ref name=":7" />
=== Social listener === A social listener is someone who engages in social listening, or [[social media monitoring]], for professional means. Social employees can use social media monitoring for a variety of reasons, including professional development, industry news and trends, and gauging market sentiment.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Best Social Media Monitoring of 2016 {{!}} Top Ten Reviews|url = http://social-media-monitoring-review.toptenreviews.com/|website = TopTenREVIEWS|access-date = 2016-01-25}}</ref><ref name=":8">{{Cite web|title = Social Listening Enables Social Business|url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/danielnewman/2014/08/26/social-listening-enables-social-business/#71445c45818a|website = Forbes|access-date = 2016-01-25|first = Daniel|last = Newman}}</ref> Some have argued that social listening is one of the most important components of social business, as it enables organizations to collect rich market data, make more informed strategic decisions, and respond to customer needs more authentically.<ref name=":8" /><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://tompeters.com/blogs/toms_videos/docs/Leadership_Listening.pdf|title = Leadership: Listening|date = |access-date = January 25, 2016|website = Tom Peters|publisher = |last = Peters|first = Tom}}</ref>
=== Customer-centric === Advocates of customer-centricity in social business argue that social media has changed the dynamic from one-way brand messaging to shared interactions between brand and customer.<ref>{{Cite web|title = To Build a Personal Brand With Social Media Takes Experimentation|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/peter-cardon/to-build-a-personal-brand_b_4887210.html|website = The Huffington Post|access-date = 2016-02-12|last = Cardon|first = Peter}}</ref> Brand and [[customer engagement]] is seen as a means of creating more lasting connections with customers and prospects and empowering them to become brand promoters.<ref>{{Cite web|title = How Collaboration Can Turn Customers into Brand Promoters|url = http://www.businessnewsdaily.com/6551-customer-collaboration-tips.html|website = Business News Daily|access-date = 2016-01-25}}</ref> Customer-centric interactions are seen to have distinct value to brands, as research shows that prospects are far more likely to trust brand-related messaging from a friend or family member than they are from a brand.<ref name=":13">{{Cite web|title = Nielsen: Global Consumers' Trust in 'Earned' Advertising Grows in Importance {{!}} Nielsen|url = http://www.nielsen.com/us/en/press-room/2012/nielsen-global-consumers-trust-in-earned-advertising-grows.html|website = www.nielsen.com|access-date = 2016-01-25}}</ref>
As a means of building social employees, some social advocates have also called for a broader definition of customer to include the employees themselves. In the book ''The Pursuit of Social Business Excellence'', authors Vala Afshar and Brad Martin made the following argument: <blockquote>A social business operates with the guiding principle that each employee’s responsibility is to serve one another, and that those we serve, even internally, are our customers. To earn internal customer trust and loyalty, each employee must be dependable, available, responsive, and committed to the success of the whole.<ref>{{Cite book|title = In Pursuit of Social Business Excellence|author1=Afshar, Vala |author2=Martin, Brad |lastauthoramp=yes |publisher = Charles Pinot|year = 2012|isbn = 0985356464|location = Sonoma|pages = Kindle locations 266–268}}</ref></blockquote>In ''The Social Employee'', authors Cheryl Burgess and Mark Burgess echo this sentiment:<blockquote>The social employee understands that every customer is an employee somewhere, and that every coworker is a customer in many other places as well. No one likes feeling ignored or otherwise disregarded by a brand. The rise of social media means that every employee with a Twitter profile is a de facto brand ambassador. Social employees are not only aware of this, they work to maximize its impact. By prizing authentic engagement and rich exchanges, the social employee is able to leverage virtual platforms toward real-world results.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Social Employee|author1=Burgess, Cheryl |author2=Burgess, Mark |lastauthoramp=yes |publisher = McGraw-Hill|year = 2013|isbn = 0071816410|location = New York|pages = 48}}</ref></blockquote>
=== Adaptable === The relatively quick proliferation and prioritization of social media in business has driven a need for organizations to be more flexible and responsive.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.ibm.com/smarterplanet/global/files/us__en_us__socialbusiness__epw14008usen.pdf|title = The Social Business: Advent of a New Age|date = 2011|access-date = January 25, 2016|website = |publisher = |last = IBM}}</ref> This in turn has led to a reprioritization of employee skill sets in which adaptability, self-directed learning, and organizational sharing are highly valued.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Skills Gap and the Seven Skill Sets that Employers Want: Building the Ideal New Hire|url = https://www.ced.org/blog/entry/the-skills-gap-and-the-seven-skill-sets-that-employers-want-building-the-id|website = Committee for Economic Development of The Conference Board|access-date = 2016-01-26|last = Herk|first = Monica}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = The 10 Unique Soft Skills Employers Desire in New Hires|url = http://www.entrepreneur.com/article/234864|website = Entrepreneur|access-date = 2016-01-26|first = Heather R.|last = Huhman}}</ref> Social training programs are commonly structured around self-directed learning modules, and employees are encouraged to share knowledge resources with others to improve organizational intelligence (see "Training").<ref name=":11">{{Cite web|title = Creating a culture of social learning {{!}} IBM Smarter Workforce Blog|url = https://www.ibm.com/blogs/smarter-workforce/2015/04/creating-a-culture-of-social-learning/|website = www.ibm.com|access-date = 2016-01-27|last = Burgess|first = Mark}}</ref>
== Common features of social employee programs == According to Weber Shandwick, 47 percent of employees are either already prepared to advocate for their employers or willing to learn. Of those, 21 percent are what the study refers to as "ProActivists," or [[early adopter]]s, employees who actively use social media for professional purposes, with about half of this group already posting about their employer through social channels.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.webershandwick.com/uploads/news/files/employees-rising-seizing-the-opportunity-in-employee-activism.pdf|title = Employees Rising: Seizing Opportunity in Employee Activism|date = April 2, 2014|access-date = January 26, 2016|website = |publisher = |last = Weber Shandwick}}</ref>
=== Pilot program === Many organizations begin with a social employee [[Pilot experiment|pilot program]] to determine best practices suitable to their organizational structure.<ref name=":7" /><ref>{{Cite web|title = Plotting Your Course with a Social Employee Pilot Program {{!}} Social Business Spotlight Blog|url = https://www.ibm.com/blogs/social-business/2015/02/10/plotting-your-course-with-a-social-employee-pilot-program/|website = www.ibm.com|access-date = 2016-02-12|last = Burgess|first = Mark}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Pilot to Deployed: Employee Advocacy is How You Scale Social|url = http://www.socialmediatoday.com/webinar/2015-03-17/pilot-deployed-employee-advocacy-how-you-scale-social|website = Social Media Today|access-date = 2016-02-12}}</ref> Program design depends in part on the size of the organization and the desired scope of social adoption. For instance, whereas [[Domo (company)|Domo]] implemented a mandatory pilot program requiring the participation of all its staff, [[Dell]] recruited approximately 200 employee participants through what was called the Social Media and Communities (SMaC) University.<ref name=":7" /><ref name=":9">{{Cite web|title = Let the games begin! Welcome to the #domosocial experiment. {{!}} Domo Blog|url = https://www.domo.com/blog/2012/05/let-the-games-begin-welcome-to-the-domosocial-experiment/|website = www.domo.com|access-date = 2016-02-12|last = James|first = Josh}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = How Dell Trained 9,000 on Social Media - SMaC U|url = http://www.tomsitpro.com/articles/social_media_training-dell_SMaC_U-social_media_and_community_university,2-330.html|website = Tom's IT Pro|date = 2012-06-19|access-date = 2016-02-12|first = David|last = Strom}}</ref>
==== Discovery ==== A common first step in a social employee pilot program is an initial process of discovery in which organizations attempt to identify and quantify their current resources. This can include a roll call of employee early adopters, an internal audit of informal adoption of social tools and practices, or a skills test to determine current adoption rates.<ref name=":9" /><ref name=":10">{{Cite web|url = https://issuu.com/oksbf/docs/s_dt_en/1|title = Piloting the Future of Social Business: Branding From the Inside Out|date = June 2014|access-date = February 11, 2016|website = |publisher = Harvard Business Review Italia|last = Burgess|first = Mark|pages = 24–29}}</ref> For instance, when Adobe conducted an internal audit, it discovered a high rate of employee social adoption. However, because different groups were using different tools across departments, informal employee tool adoption was found to have a negative effect on productivity, creating redundancies and [[Information silo|silos]].<ref name=":7" /><ref name=":10" />
==== Social computing policy ==== Many organizations will recruit employees to actively participate in designing the pilot program. A fundamental concern of social media use in business has been its potential for abuse—specifically regarding the release of confidential information, negative or off-brand messages, and security risks.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Should employees be allowed to use social networks at work?|url = https://www.socialmediaexplorer.com/social-media-marketing/employees-on-social-networks/|website = Social Media Explorer|access-date = 2016-02-12|language = en-US|last = Falls|first = Jason}}</ref> Because of this, one focus in many social employee pilot programs has been to establish a set of social media guidelines. For example, IBM created an internal wiki and invited employees to help build a document laying out acceptable social engagement guidelines.<ref name=":6" /> This document has since been adopted by several other organizations.<ref name=":7" />
==== Training ==== To social organizations, social employee training helps to unify employee programs and tools throughout the organization and establishes a common knowledge base and set of [[best practice]]s to assist employees in sharing and decision-making.<ref name=":7" /><ref name=":3" /> Many organizations us a combination of in-person training, digital learning modules, and [[Social learning theory|social learning]] principles.
Social employee training often applies the [[70/20/10 Model|70/20/10 learning model]] as its basis. In this model, 70 percent of learning is self-directed, 20 percent is informal mentoring or coaching, and 10 percent is formal training. Applying this dynamic, many organizations work to design a "digital learning experience" in which employees can access learning modules and other subject-specific content to help them acquire new skills.<ref name=":11" /><ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.bersin.com/blog/post/Predictions-for-2015--Redesigning-the-Organization-for-A-Rapidly-Changing-World.aspx | title = Predictions for 2015: Redesigning the Organization for A Rapidly Changing World | website = www.bersin.com | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref>
Training is often divided into mandatory basic skills modules and optional advanced skills modules. To determine what social knowledge an employee needs, a baseline or "social IQ" test is often administered.<ref name=":7" /><ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.domo.com/news/media/qa-assessing-the-social-media-payoff | title = Media - Q&A: Assessing the Social Media Payoff {{!}} Domo | website = www.domo.com | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref> Many organizations, such as Adobe with its Center of Excellence (CoE) and Dell with its SMaC University, have expanded their training programs to establish a more permanent resource for employees.<ref name=":7" /><ref>{{Cite web|title = 4 Top Employers for Social Media Professionals|url = http://mashable.com/2010/12/14/top-companies-social-media-professionals/|website = Mashable|access-date = 2016-02-12|first = Amy-Mae|last = Elliott}}</ref>
Because social employee best practices affect organizational practice and culture in a broad way, upper management and executives are also encouraged to adopt social engagement best practices. Doing so is said to help drive buy-in among the workforce and reinforce organizational commitment to the program. Training for upper management and executives can often involve a process known as "reverse mentoring," in which a lower-level employee is brought in to help develop a senior-level manager's skills and basic digital literacy.<ref name=":7" /><ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/joshsteimle/2015/05/05/reverse-mentoring-investing-in-tomorrows-business-strategy/#5f4d85df666d | title = Reverse Mentoring - Investing in Tomorrow's Business Strategy | website = Forbes | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970203764804577060051461094004 | title = Reverse Mentoring Cracks Workplace | last = Kwoh | first = Leslie | newspaper = Wall Street Journal | issn = 0099-9660 | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref>
=== Social engagement and content marketing === Social engagement and sharing through both internal and external channels are considered key components of social employee design. Employees are encouraged to communicate with coworkers, customers, prospects, and stakeholders through social channels by sharing industry-related news or user-generated content.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://marketingland.com/5-research-based-findings-prove-content-marketing-better-native-advertising-129953 | title = 5 Research-Based Findings Show Content Marketing Beats Native Advertising | website = Marketing Land | language = en-US | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref>
Internally, this process is often centered on keeping employees updated on company and industry news, helping employees collaborate on projects, and building culture. Many [[Enterprise social software|enterprise-level social platforms]] have been developed to facilitate such objectives, including task management platforms, wikis, file-sharing tools, and messaging services.<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://hbr.org/2013/07/the-real-power-of-enterprise-s.html | title = The Real Power of Enterprise Social Media Platforms | website = Harvard Business Review | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref>
Externally, the focus is often on customer engagement, often through content marketing practices. Research has shown that social sharing can have a positive impact on metrics such as brand engagement, web traffic, and sales.<ref name=":14" /> The advent of digital commerce has led customers to research products more thoroughly before make a purchase decision, using social reviews, peer recommendations, and product-specific content to help guide their decisions.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://bluefocusmarketing.com/2016/02/18/do-social-reviews-really-help-your-business-socialemployee-book-review/ | title = Do Social Reviews Really Help Your Business? | last = Burgess | first = Cheryl | date = February 18, 2016 | website = Blue Focus Marketing | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref> Because of the value of peer recommendations specifically, a primary of goal of content marketing is to encourage customers and prospects to share the content among their personal networks as a form of "earned" advocacy.<ref name=":13" /><ref name=":14" />
Another popular social engagement strategy with stakeholders is resharing advocate-generated content through branded channels. This is believed to strengthen relationships with stakeholders and help to humanize the brand.<ref name=":15" />
=== Assessment === Measuring the success social employee advocacy programs has presented a challenge to many organizations. While a small percentage of organizations assert that they are able to measure and validate their investment in social marketing, a larger percentage is either only qualitatively aware of the success of their social efforts or unable to measure whatsoever.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.cmosurvey.org/ | title = The CMO Survey | website = www.cmosurvey.org | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref>
Social business thought leaders argue that assessing the success of social employee programs must take into account more than financial [[return on investment]] (ROI).<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.garyvaynerchuk.com/social-media-roi-calculate-metrics/ | title = What’s the ROI of Your Mother? | last = Vaynerchuck | first = Gary | date = December 2015 | website = GaryVaynerchuk.com | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref> Companies that consider a broader set of metrics than financial return often measure success through a variety of key performance indicators: * Number of employee profile views and connections<ref name=":12" /> * Number of leads from social channels<ref name=":14" /> * Rate at which employee network grows<ref name=":7" /><ref name=":12" /><ref name=":14" /> * Frequency of shares and interactions<ref name=":7" /> * Increase in online "chatter" about a brand<ref name=":14" /> * Ability to attract and retain skilled talent<ref name=":12" /> * Increases in visibility, inbound web traffic, brand recognition, and brand loyalty<ref name=":14" /> Many organizations, however, do report financial benefits as well. Social employees are more likely to exceed their sales quota, and social businesses in general are more likely to see increased sales leads and increase in revenues.<ref name=":12" /><ref name=":14" />
=== Gamification, engagement, and culture-building programs === Culture-building programs vary in scope and complexity, but all use social media in some way to underscore employee, departmental, or organizational accomplishments.<ref name=":7" /><ref name=":3" /> Program leaders will issue social engagement challenges to help employees meet goals. Challenges can include number of connections (i.e., [[Like button|likes]] or follows, [[Reblogging|retweets]]), number of leads, or frequency of posts (i.e., status updates, [[Tweets (Twitter)|tweets]], [[blog]]s, etc.).<ref name=":2" /> For a more competitive element, some organizations will employ [[gamification]] strategies such as leaderboards, achievement badges, and scavenger hunts.<ref name=":7" /><ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/danschawbel/2013/10/07/adam-penenberg-how-gamification-is-going-to-change-the-workplace/#2d1a1f7739e5 | title = Adam Penenberg: How Gamification Is Going To Change The Workplace | website = Forbes | access-date = 2016-02-27 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.socialmediatoday.com/content/gamification-more-just-buzzword | title = Is Gamification More Than Just a Buzzword? | last = Coombe | first = Jesse | website = Social Media Today | access-date = 2016-02-27 }}</ref>

{{Use Pakistani English|date=October 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | name = Tajal Bewas | native_name = {{lang-sd|'''تاجل بيوس'''}} | native_name_lang = sd | image = | imagesize = | caption = | pseudonym = "بيوس" | birth_name = Taj Mohammed Samoo | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1938|09|22}} | birth_place = Village Dargah Pir Hayat Shah, [[Taluka]] [[Sobho Dero]], [[Khairpur]], [[Sindh]] | death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|2008|12|13|1938|09|22}} | death_place = [[Karachi]], [[Sindh]] | occupation = Poet, Prose Writer and Journalist | nationality = | citizenship = | education = [[Master of Arts]], [[Economics]] | alma_mater = [[University of Sindh]], [[Jamshoro]] | period = | genre = [[Aesthetic]] | subject = [[Poetry]], [[Journalism]] | movement = [[Progressivism|Progressive]] | notableworks = Poetry Books | spouse = | partner = | children = | relatives = | awards = | signature = | website = | portaldisp = }} '''Tajal Bewas''' (original name Taj Mohammed Samoo) ({{lang-sd|'''تاجل بيوس'''}}) was born on 22 September 1938 in [[Village]] Dargah Pir Hayat Shah, [[Taluka]] [[Sobho Dero]], [[Khairpur]], [[Sindh]]. He was a Sindhi- and Urdu-language poet, novelist, short-story writer, teacher and government official.<ref name=jktb/> He died on 13 December 2008 due to [[brain hemorrhage]] in [[Karachi]].<ref>http://www.encyclopediasindhiana.org/article.php?Dflt=%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%AC%D9%84%20%D8%A8%D9%8A%D9%88%D8%B3</ref>
==Life== Bewas was born in Pir Hayat Shah village, Khairpur district. His received his education from local schools and the Gambat High School before completing a Master of Arts degree in Economics as an external candidate with Sindh University.{{Citation needed|date= July 2012}} After completing his education, he taught English in his home town.<ref name=tntb>No byline, [http://www.nation.com.pk/pakistan-news-newspaper-daily-english-online/Regional/Karachi/14-Dec-2008/Tajal-Bewas-dies-at-70 "Tajal Bewas dies at 70"], article, ''The Nation'', 15 December 2008, retrieved 14 December 2008.</ref>
Bewas also served as a government official before his retirement, and was registrar for several companies. He was also a secretary for the Pakistani government and registrar of companies for the government of Sindh province.<ref name=jktb>Khaskheli, Jan, [http://www.thenews.com.pk/print1.asp? id=151776 "Tajal Bewas passes away"], ''The News'', 14 December 2008, retrieved same day.</ref>
He was a resident of Karachi when he died at 70. A week before his death, he had a stroke and was sent to at Liaquat National Hospital, where he died. Bewas had arranged musical programs at Chowkundi graveyard, a historical cemetery, and was buried there, as he had wanted.<ref name=ntobit/>
Upon his death, ''[[The Nation (Pakistani newspaper)|The Nation]]'' called Bewas "legendary"<ref name=tntb/> and ''The News International'' called him "renowned".<ref name=jktb/>
His poem, "Sindh Munhji Aman Soonh Tuhinji Mathan Chha Likhi Chha Likhan" is considered "the national anthem of Sindhis in India", according to ''[[The Regional Times of Sindh|The Regional Times]]'', which reported after his death: "He was known across Pakistan and India and many singers of both countries sung his poetry for radio and television".<ref name=ntobit>Turk, Niaz, [http://regionaltimes.com/14dec2008/backpagenews/sindh.htm "Renowned Sindhi poet Tajal Bewas passes away"], ''The Regional Times'', 14 December 2008, retrieved same day.</ref> Bewas was the author of 44 books, 34 of them published, including ''Andaz-e-Bayan Aur'', a collection of Urdu poetry.
"He tried to experiment in all native and modern forms of poetry" and was called a Sindhi classical form "Bait", ''[[The News International]]'' of Karachi reported upon his death.<ref name=jktb/> Fellow [[Sindhi language|Sindhi]] poet Naseer Soomro said after his death that "I always saw Tajal Bewas not only as a great poet but a generous human being too. He was aware of the techniques of the poetry and rhythms of music."<ref>"[https://www.thenews.com.pk/archive/print/150532-Contempt-notice-issued-to-Punjab-IG-Prisons-in-detention-case Tajal Bewas passes away,]" [[The News International]], 14 December 2008.</ref>

{{Redirect|Kua|other uses|KUA (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox language |name=Tsoa |altname=Kua |nativename=Hiechware |states=[[Botswana]], [[Zimbabwe]] |speakers=2,000 |date=2013 |ref={{Cite news|url=https://www.ethnologue.com/language/hio|title=Tsoa|work=Ethnologue|access-date=2018-05-22|language=en}} |familycolor=Khoisan |fam1=[[Khoe languages|Khoe]] |fam2=Kalahari (Tshu–Khwe) |fam3=East |dia1=Hiechware |dia2=Kua |dia3=Cire Cire |nation={{flag|Zimbabwe}} (as 'Koisan') | lc1 = hio |ld1=Tsoa | lc2 = tyu |ld2=Kua |notice=IPA |glotto=tshw1239 |glottorefname=Tshwa }} '''Tsoa''' or '''Tshwa''', also known as '''Kua''' and '''Hiechware''', is an [[East Kalahari Khoe]] dialect cluster spoken by several thousand people in [[Botswana]] and [[Zimbabwe]]. (This language group is not to be confused with [[Tswa language|Tswa]] (Xitswa), a Bantu language in Mozambique which has the alternate spelling Tshwa.) One of the dialects is [[Tjwao dialect|Tjwao]] (formerly Tshwao), the only Khoisan language in Zimbabwe, where "Koisan" is a language officially recognised in the constitution. ==Dialects== Tsoa–Kua is a [[dialect cluster]], which is still poorly studied but seems to include: *'''Tsoa''', also known as '''Hiechware''' and as various other combinations of Hio-, Hie-, Hai- + Chwa, Tshwa, Chuwau, Tshuwau + -re, -ri; also as Sarwa, Sesarwa (the Tswana name), Gǁabake-Ntshori, Tati, and Kwe-Etshori Kwee. Zimbabwean Tshwao apparently belongs here. *'''Kua''', also spelled Cua and Tyhua. That is, both Tsoa and Kua may be pronounced something like {{IPA|[tʃwa]}}, and it's not clear that they are distinct dialects. *'''Cire Cire''' {{IPA|[tʃire tʃire]}}, spoken in the area around Nata in Botswana. ==Phonology== The Cire-cire (not cited) dialect has the following [[consonant]] inventory: {| class="wikitable" align="center" |+ Consonant phonemes of the Cire-cire dialect (not cited) |- ! ! [[Bilabial consonant|Bilabial]] ! [[Dental consonant|Dental]] ! [[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] ! [[Lateral consonant|Lateral]] ! [[Postalveolar consonant|Post-
alveolar]] ! [[Velar consonant|Velar]] ! [[Uvular consonant|Uvular]] ! [[Glottal consonant|Glottal]] |- align=center ! [[Nasal click]] | |    {{IPA link|ᵑǀ}} |    ({{IPA link|ᵑǃ}}) |    {{IPA link|ᵑǁ}} |    ({{IPA link|ᵑǂ}}) | | | |- align=center ! [[Oral consonant|Oral]] [[click consonant|click]] | | {{IPA link|ǀ}} {{IPA link|ᶢǀ}} {{IPA|ǀʰ}} | ({{IPA link|ǃ}} {{IPA link|ᶢǃ}} {{IPA|ǃʰ}}) | {{IPA link|ǁ}} {{IPA link|ᶢǁ}} {{IPA|ǁʰ}} | ({{IPA link|ǂ}} {{IPA link|ᶢǂ}} {{IPA|ǂʰ}}) | | | |- align=center ! [[Glottalized click]] | |    {{IPA link|ǀˀ}} | |    {{IPA link|ǁˀ}} | | | | |- align=center ! [[Affricate click]] | | {{IPA|   (ǀqχ)}} | | {{IPA|   (ǁqχ)}} | | | | |- align=center ! [[Nasal stop]] | {{IPA|   m}} | | {{IPA|   n}} | | | | | |- align=center ! [[Stop consonant|Oral stop]] | {{IPA|p   b}} | | {{IPA|t   d}} | | | {{IPA|k   ɡ}} | {{IPA|q   }} | {{IPA|ʔ   }} |- align=center ! [[Affricate consonant|Affricate]] | | |{{IPA|   dz}} | | {{IPA|tʃ   dʒ}} | | | |- align=center ! [[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] | | | {{IPA|s   z}} | | {{IPA|ʃ   }} | | {{IPA|χ   }} | |- align=center ! [[Approximant consonant|Approximant]] | | | |{{IPA|   l}} | | | | |} The clicks have a very uneven distribution: Only a dozen words begin with one of the palatal clicks ({{IPA|ǂ}}), and these are replaced by dental clicks ({{IPA|ǀ}}) among younger speakers. Only half a dozen words start with one of the alveolar clicks ({{IPA|ǃ}}), and half a dozen more with one of the affricated clicks. These rather marginal sounds are placed in parentheses in the chart. Tsoa has the five vowels {{IPA|/a e i o u/}}. It is not clear if Tsoa has long vowels, or simply sequences of identical vowels {{IPA|/aa ee ii oo uu/}}. There are two tones, high and low, plus a few cases of mid tone. In the northern dialect of Kua, like all other East Kalahari Khoe languages, the palatal click series has become palatal stops. Southern Kua has retained the palatal clicks, but the dental stops have palatalized, as they have in [[Gǀui language|Gǀui]] and [[ǂ’Amkoe language|ǂ’Amkoe]]. Thus northern Kua has {{IPA|/ɟua/}} 'ash' and {{IPA|/d̪u/}} 'eland', whereas southern Kua has {{IPA|ᶢǂua}} 'ash' and {{IPA|/d̪ʲu/}} (or perhaps {{IPA|/ɟu/}}) 'eland'.Gerlach, Linda (2015) "Phonetic and phonological description of the Nǃaqriaxe variety of ǂ’Amkoe and the impact of language contact".
